Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Discovering Insulating Topological Insulators
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract:
At the heart of electronic devices lies silicon, a semiconductor material that can be made
pure enough for high performance and is amenable to mass production. While such
circuitry is continually improving, silicon is unable to exhibit quantum phenomena
required for complete solutions in weather prediction, genomics, and secure encryption.
A new class of materials, the so-called topological insulators, holds the promise to
realize such phenomena and revolutionize computing. Topological insulators are, in
theory, non-metallic in the interior of the material but behave like a metal at the surface.
In addition, the quantum character of these metallic electrons can be switched, which is
the basic information processing function. While known topological insulators
demonstrate the metallic surface state, these materials have not been made pure enough
for incorporating into electronic devices. Specifically, they are not yet insulating in the
interior. This project will seek to find new topological insulators and to engineer them to
levels of purity needed for an insulating interior and satisfy the performance demands of
electronic circuits. The project will impact the electronics industry as well as train
graduates skilled in the computational and experimental techniques of this new class of
materials.

Technical abstract:
The goal of the project is to create topological insulator materials that are pure enough in
the bulk to exhibit true insulating behavior. Topological insulators are found among
high-Z atom containing semiconductors with band gaps small enough that the spin-orbit
coupling related to the large Z-number can invert the conduction and valence band.
These materials must also possess spatial inversion symmetry for the relevant orbitals.
The project will explore candidate materials classes among pseudo-binary and
pyrochlore-related structures containing heavy metals such as Ir, Re, and Os. Materials
synthesis by solid state chemistry techniques will be guided by simulations based on
density functional theory. Promising candidate materials will be synthesized in single
crystal form by appropriate methods including vapor transport, zone refinement, and
growth from flux. Crystalline specimens will be studied with angle resolved
photoemission spectroscopy and conventional charge transport techniques. Prototype
transistor devices will be fabricated on a smaller subset of these systems. The results at
each measurement stage will be fed back to the theory and synthesis efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was proposed to discover new materials in the general area of topological systems. Topological materials are characterized by having electronic energy levels which, when expressed in terms of electron momentum, possess a character similar to that which distinguishes a ball from a donut. Both are round, but one has a hole in it, which places the donut in a different topological class. Materials possessing electronic levels with such topological character can possess unusual properties such as metallic behavior on the surface of an otherwise non-metallic, or insulating, interior.  These surface electrons also possess an internal magnetism (spin) that is locked to their direction of travel. For example, left-going electrons have spin up while right-going electrons have spin down. This property has potential use in new types of electronic devices that employ spin, rather than charge, as the bit of information which can in turn lead to faster and more energy efficient electronics.

At present, two major classes of topological electronic materials have been studied, topological insulators and Weyl semimetals. Another class of topological materials studied under this project is low-dimensional insulating magnets that are geometrically frustrated and predicted to exhibit "topological order" with attendant magnetic surface states. Our project involved combining chemistry and physics approaches to search within these classes of materials for potential topological behavior. Research was performed at five different universities. Theoretical guidance came from the University California Davis. New materials were made at Oregon State University and known materials were made in single crystal form at Florida State University. Magnetic and thermal measurements were made on these materials at the University of California Santa Cruz and angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy was done at the University of Colorado.

The project produced a total of 39 peer-reviewed publications. Highlights from those publications that contain a substantial contribution from the Ramirez group at University of California Santa Cruz are as follows. * We discovered a variety of quantum magnetic states in the new compound series known as the "tripod-kagome" family, M2Ln3Sb3O14, where M is either Mg or Zn and Ln is a lanthanide, or rare-earth, ion. These materials are rare examples of quasi-two dimensional systems possessing lanthanide ions and future work will involve single crystal growth and characterization.  * In the quasi-one-dimensional compound K2PbCu(NO2)6, which is a member of the Elpasolite mineral family, we discovered an anomalously large shift of excitations down to nearly zero temperature, where quantum effects dominate. This result shows that a magnetic field can be used to create high-density quantum matter.  * In URu2Si2, we discovered cosine-to-the-fourth-power behavior in angular dependence of the non-linear susceptibility discontinuity at the hidden order transition. This result supports a theory of "hastatic order" that describes how the local and itinerant electrons in this material can strongly interact.  * In the pyrochlore system Y2Ir2O7, predicted to be a magnetic Weyl semimetal, we found that the conductivity varies as the fourth power of temperature, validating a theory of charged disorder scattering in such systems. * We also discovered the first system, Li2.15Os0.85O3, in which Osmium occupies a honeycomb lattice, and observed anomalous behavior in the thermal properties at ultra-low temperatures. The honeycomb lattice forms a template for a certain type of topological magnetic order when occupied by large spin-orbit-coupled atoms such as Osmium. This compound will be important to understand at a deeper level.
